headline: Lululemon Faces Further Pain Ahead as Casual Offerings Grow Stale
summary: Jefferies analyst Randal Konik said that the company’s second consecutive cut to its annual outlook shows it has lost visibility into its business as it contends with volatile sales.  “When you see something like that, it means that while the brand’s relevant, it’s becoming less relevant,” Konik said, noting that Lululemon was the “it” brand during the Covid-19 pandemic.  Much of next year’s performance will hinge on whether the company can spark demand with new casual styles, William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia said, acknowledging its performance apparel continues to draw shoppers.

raw.headline: Lululemon Faces Further Pain Ahead as Casual Offerings Grow Stale
raw.summary: Jefferies analyst Randal Konik said that the company’s second consecutive cut to its annual outlook shows it has lost visibility into its business as it contends with volatile sales.  “When you see something like that, it means that while the brand’s relevant, it’s becoming less relevant,” Konik said, noting that Lululemon was the “it” brand during the Covid-19 pandemic.  Much of next year’s performance will hinge on whether the company can spark demand with new casual styles, William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia said, acknowledging its performance apparel continues to draw shoppers.

headline: Lululemon slides as weak US demand, tariff costs cloud holiday outlook
summary: Lululemon Athletica's shares slumped 20% before the bell after the Canadian yogawear retailer signaled a tepid holiday season, citing lackluster demand and steep tariff costs. The company, which was hopeful until recently that its weekly launches would boost demand, slashed its 2025 sales and profit forecasts on Thursday. It also expects a significant hit from the U.S. ending the "de minimis" exemption, which allowed shipments under $800 to enter duty-free.

raw.headline: Lululemon slides as weak US demand, tariff costs cloud holiday outlook
raw.summary: Lululemon Athletica's shares slumped 20% before the bell after the Canadian yogawear retailer signaled a tepid holiday season, citing lackluster demand and steep tariff costs. The company, which was hopeful until recently that its weekly launches would boost demand, slashed its 2025 sales and profit forecasts on Thursday. It also expects a significant hit from the U.S. ending the "de minimis" exemption, which allowed shipments under $800 to enter duty-free.

headline: Stocks to Watch Friday: Broadcom, DocuSign, Lululemon
summary: ↗️ Broadcom (AVGO): The semiconductor and software maker swung to a profit and surpassed expectations for quarterly sales. Shares rose 9.5% in Friday premarket trading. ↘️ Lululemon (LULU): The maker of athletic wear cut its outlook, saying it expected higher tariffs and the end of the de minimis exemption to dent its fiscal-year profit by $240 million.

headline: LULU Q2 Deep Dive: U.S. Product Weakness and Tariff Pressures Shape Outlook
summary: Athletic apparel retailer Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) fell short of the market’s revenue expectations in Q2 CY2025, but sales rose 6.5% year on year to $2.53 billion. Next quarter’s revenue guidance of $2.49 billion underwhelmed, coming in 2.7% below analysts’ estimates. Its GAAP profit of $3.10 per share was 8.7% above analysts’ consensus estimates.
